Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of Mating Communication in Moths: Role of Male Courtship Pheromones
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall goal of this project is to understand male-female communication in animals by integrating mechanistic research at the biochemical-genetic-behavioral levels with experimental and observational research in the field, and with research that addresses evolutionary questions. This project will elucidate the chemical structures of signal molecules and blends (pheromones) used in moth mating communication, quantify behaviors elicited by these chemicals, uncover mechanisms of pheromone production and reception, and identify genes that underlie all these processes. This project will lead to a better understanding of the evolution of pheromone blends in females and response profiles in males and females among populations and across closely related species. Because many moth species are important pests in agricultural crops, forests and stored grains, this research has practical significance for society through the discovery of new tools for ecologically based pest control. This project will train a postdoctoral researcher and a graduate student in a multidisciplinary environment that includes quantitative analysis of behavior, chemical ecology, neuroscience and genetics. A unique feature of this project is the collaboration with the University of Amsterdam in the Netherlands and the Max Planck Institute of Chemical Ecology in Germany, which will offer the postdoctoral researcher and graduate student unique training in evolutionary, chemical, and molecular biology in a collaborative international setting. The project will recruit and train undergraduates from underrepresented demographics from North Carolina State University and nearby Historically Black Universities. It will develop outreach programs, including hands-on interactive exercises and discussions in biodiversity, animal behavior and evolutionary biology. Finally, trainees in this project will participate in public education and engagement events, including BugFest (the largest STEM education program in the US with ~35,000 participants annually), Science Caf√©s, the Science of Attraction (300 participants in 2014), and other public education programs.

Three major questions in animal sexual communication motivate this project: 1) What features of close-range male sexual signals affect female choice; 2) What information do components of the male's complex signal convey to the female; and 3) Is the production of male sexual signals biochemically and genetically linked to production of female signals. Answers to these questions are critical not only for understanding the roles of reciprocal signaling and mate choice in the evolution of sexual communication systems in animals, but will also lead to a better understanding of how the evolution of mating preferences can lead to reproductive isolation among populations, and ultimately to the origin of new species. Researchers have largely ignored close-range courtship behavior by male moths, including the release of close-range sex pheromones, female assessment of the male pheromone, preference, and ultimately acceptance or rejection of the male. This project is based on the recent discovery of novel compounds in the male pheromone gland, some of which share biosynthetic origins with female-produced pheromones, while others are chemically unrelated and may be sequestered from larval and adult food. This dual chemistry can provide females with a dual assessment of the male's ability to (a) de novo biosynthesize pheromone compounds similar to hers, and (b) acquire essential nutrients, and grow on a well-defended plant. This project integrates insect mate choice with insect-plant interaction strategies and investigates the new male compounds as a novel class of sexual signaling molecules in insects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merits:

Evolutionary theory is based on an apparent contradiction: Natural populations maintain considerable genetic variation in various traits, despite strong natural and sexual selection that should deplete variation in these traits. This paradox is especially apparent in sexual communication: Signal and response seem to be under strong stabilizing selection, yet the impressive diversity of animal species and the sexual signals they use shows that signal radiation has not been stymied. Close-range male pheromones in moths, and female choice based on the male’s pheromones, are especially important in the evolution of sexual communication because of (a) the potential biochemical and genetic linkage between female and male pheromones, (b) the potential linkage between female pheromones and female choice, and therefore, (c) the potential that female long-range pheromones, male close-range pheromones, and female choice are intricately linked.

The overall goal of this project was to understand the chemical communication system of Heliothis virescens (chemistry, behavior, genetic architecture), and to apply this information to a broader understanding of the evolution of sexual communication systems and to innovative pest management approaches. Most of the male’s close-range signals are chemically similar to the female’s pheromone and possibly genetically and biochemically linked to the female signals. However, we found novel components of apparent plant origin in the close-range male sexual signal that may serve important functions in sexual selection.

Is the production of male sexual signals genetically and biochemically linked to production of female signals? Artificial selection that greatly decreased the main pheromone component in females also decreased a related pheromone component in males. This finding suggests that as female choice drives divergence among populations in the male pheromone, her own pheromone—and possibly mate choice itself—may undergo selection pressure that counters the strong stabilizing selection usually associated with long-range sexual signals.

What features of close-range male sexual signals affect female behavior? Using the female antenna as a biological detector coupled to a gas chromatograph, we found four unusual apparently plant-derived compounds in male pheromone gland extracts and air-borne collections that elicit strong electrophysiological responses in female antennae. These compounds were not found in diet-reared males, but males sequester them from host plant leaves into their pheromone gland. Behavioral studies documented a role for one of these compounds in mating behavior, and two olfactory receptors in the female antennae responded to this compound, one broadly tuned and the other finely tuned to the plant-derived compound. Work in progress is examining the role of these receptors in behavior, including knockout of the receptors with CRISP approaches. Overall, results suggest that males use a dual strategy in their close-range communication with females—they not only share pheromone biosynthetic pathways with females, but they also sequester plant-derived compounds into their pheromone glands.

Do male-produced sexual signals play a role in male-male competition? Results showed that the male perfumes the female with his sex pheromone and it functions as an anti-aphrodisiac. This perfuming can be regarded as post-copulatory chemical mate guarding, because the anti-aphrodisiac compounds maximize the male’s paternity. In mating experiments and olfactometer orientation assays we found that the plant-derived compound also functions as a short term anti-aphrodisiac.

Broader impacts:

This project trained 4 postdoctoral researchers, 2 visiting international scientists, 3 PhD students and 8 undergraduate students. All personnel involved in this project conducted many community outreach activities, including hands-on STEM sessions for elementary school classes, an annual BugFest event that draws 35,000 people, and Brain and Behavior Night at the NC Museum of Natural Sciences. A postdoc lead a seminar series on statistical analysis and another postdoc taught a class in chemical ecology. Several publications related to this project were covered in the scientific and popular media. By clarifying what signal traits males use and to which of these females respond, we can develop new and more accurate/specific monitoring systems and fine-tune existing technologies. Knowing what traits affect female-male communication and mate choice is important for innovative trapping and trap-and-kill technologies.
